document.title: New Jersey Student Learning Standards English Language Arts (NJSLS-ELA)

917C27FB74994E4C86F7C98AFB9D3447.description:
Adapt speech to a variety of contexts and tasks, demonstrating command of formal English
when indicated or appropriate.

49D2A9EDABDB4FDFB68332F147FC05E2.description:
Integrate multimedia and visual displays into presentations to clarify information, strengthen
claims and evidence, and add interest.

B647A19B1E5349BFBAF8560F4A407517.description:
Present claims and findings, emphasizing salient points in a focused, coherent manner with
relevant evidence, sound valid reasoning, and well-chosen details; use appropriate eye contact,
adequate volume, and clear pronunciation.

D1B049A2259849C49B130109BAAA213A.description:
Delineate a speaker’s argument and specific claims, evaluating the soundness of the reasoning
and relevance and sufficiency of the evidence and identifying when irrelevant evidence is introduced.

25426461F12B4803BAF93076C96D1F4F.description:
Analyze the purpose of information presented in diverse media and formats (e.g., visually,
quantitatively, orally) and evaluate the motives (e.g., social, commercial, political) behind its
presentation.

330D26D7919244E48AB831503F7B1699.description:
Acknowledge new information expressed by others, and, when warranted, qualify or justify
their own views in light of the evidence presented.

623416CEB2164867929D97E7274EC69A.description:
Pose questions that connect the ideas of several speakers and respond to others’ questions
and comments with relevant evidence, observations, and ideas.

14EB457F4EFD450792C7211A4707DE84.description:
Follow rules for collegial discussions and decision-making, track progress toward specific
goals and deadlines, and define individual roles as needed.

C1E1463A27974A3D9A1489A5C24B724D.description:
Come to discussions prepared, having read or researched material under study; explicitly
draw on that preparation by referring to evidence on the topic, text, or issue to probe and
reflect on ideas under discussion.

9384A86E60644B6C85139C455CF1329B.description:
Engage effectively in a range of collaborative discussions (one-on-one, in groups, and
teacher-led) with diverse partners on grade 8 topics, texts, and issues, building on others’ ideas and
expressing their own clearly.

7ED9648C4CFC430F93B388481A8A3C3C.description:
Write routinely over extended time frames (time for research, reflection, metacognition/selfcorrection, and revision) and shorter time frames (a single sitting or a day or two) for a range of
discipline-specific tasks, purposes, and audiences.

0707EE83E3BE48BFA5DF8BBF3CC40421.description:
Gather relevant information from multiple print and digital sources, using search terms
effectively; assess the credibility and accuracy of each source; and quote or paraphrase the data and
conclusions of others while avoiding plagiarism and following a standard format for citation.

F535179B031241849EEFB564C39AA6A4.description:
Conduct short research projects to answer a question (including a self-generated question),
drawing on several sources and generating additional related, focused questions that allow for multiple
avenues of exploration.

8F3DE19A3A89470E96ABCDD702BECDAB.description:
With some guidance and support from peers and adults, develop and strengthen writing as
needed by planning, sustaining effort to complete complex writing tasks; seeking out assistance, models,
sources or feedback to improve understanding or refine final products; focusing on how well purpose
and audience have been addressed.

459E3E1DE49547A9AF98ADB67C0BF5A9.description: Provide a conclusion that follows from and reflects on the narrated experiences or events.

9792E5F6D0554552A9F88AB6B2CD8C3B.description:
Use precise words and phrases, relevant descriptive details, and sensory language to capture
the action and convey experiences and events.

2EBC3E22C45947D3B8738F6BC96FD180.description:
Use a variety of transition words, phrases, and clauses to convey sequence, signal shifts from
one time frame or setting to another, and show the relationships among experiences and
events.

436B2FD182B04A638DE0EE3A10C95507.description:
Use narrative techniques, such as dialogue, pacing, description, and reflection, to develop
experiences, events, and/or characters.

18A55A7F116F4BACA38D9538E07800FF.description:
Engage and orient the reader by establishing a context and point of view and introducing a
narrator and/or characters; organize an event sequence that unfolds naturally and logically.

3C61FF21E1924F1CAEAC5243772994CB.description:
Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique,
relevant descriptive details, and well-structured event sequences.

727F5F2A4B1E40BD90D73F719FD69746.description:
Provide a concluding statement or section (e.g., sentence, part of a paragraph, paragraph, or
multiple paragraphs) that synthesizes the information or explanation presented.

CA35B57E2225477BA0242AE63748D020.description: Establish and maintain a formal style/academic style, approach, and form.

5174754A4E9F4E16AE4D62E5B7C6327E.description:
Use precise language and domain/grade-level- specific vocabulary to inform about or explain
the topic.

5570CBAFC96C4A66B3BDD9E5130A4D5D.description:
Use appropriate transitions to create cohesion and clarify the relationships among ideas and
concepts.

556E659B7A77432CB686766027AC2A0F.description:
Develop the topic with relevant, well-chosen facts, definitions, concrete details, quotations,
or other information and examples.

407B0D06B2754FBFADA9A4CAFFDA44F0.description:
Introduce a topic clearly, previewing what is to follow; and organize ideas, concepts, and
information, using text structures (e.g., definition, classification, comparison/contrast,
cause/effect, etc.) and text features (e.g., headings, graphics, and multimedia) when useful
to aid in comprehension.

49E7E2E593DF462E902F9C0A9E74215F.description:
Write informative/explanatory texts (including the narration of historical events, scientific
procedures/ experiments, or technical processes) to examine a topic and convey ideas, concepts, and
information through the selection, organization, and analysis of relevant content.

0997899F170E4CCF8C9CA8928A5B7484.description:
Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the argument
presented.

0605CE7DCF5845FA8CFE22ED00B61A7C.description: Establish and maintain a formal or academic style, approach, and form.

66105C5C808B424FBC25F979F2733039.description:
Use words, phrases, and clauses to create cohesion and clarify the relationships among
claim(s), counterclaims, reasons, and evidence.

74E74A86FCF242C1BC88C9F0BEEAB6FE.description:
Support claim(s) with logical reasoning and relevant evidence, using relevant, accurate data
and evidence that demonstrate an understanding of the topic or text, using credible sources.

003FF30A37D441AF996BBDEAF738DF27.description:
Introduce claim(s) about a topic or issue, acknowledge and distinguish the claim(s) from
alternate or opposing claims, and organize the reasons and evidence logically.

7A2E10683C1040428E47850D397B82C6.description:
Write arguments on discipline-specific content (e.g., social studies, science, technical subjects,
English/Language Arts) to support claims with clear reasons and relevant evidence.

84A8108E669849BFBF03E2417CED7E26.description:
Analyze and reflect on (e.g., practical knowledge, historical/cultural context, and background
knowledge) two or more informational texts that provide conflicting information on the same topic and
identify where the texts disagree on matters of fact or interpretation.

2749FA320BE54E1EBEA0EDDA4DE0668F.description:
Analyze and reflect on how the author’s idea in fiction and literary nonfiction texts (e.g.,
practical knowledge, historical/cultural context, and background knowledge) is shaped by the author’s
emphasis on different evidence, advancing different interpretations of facts, or fictional portrayal of a
time, place, or character and a historical account of the same period.

6296E865A11243E48BC980B008F90D25.description:
Delineate and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the
reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient; recognize when irrelevant evidence is
introduced.

D3A01ABAB47C4AAE940ED2B8453E7E6E.description:
Evaluate the choices made (by the authors, directors, or actors) when presenting an idea in
different mediums and the advantages and disadvantages of using different mediums or formats (e.g.,
visually, quantitatively) to address a question or solve a problem.

62C8E5D130F145C999F57769A8EF0938.description:
Evaluate the choices made (by the authors, directors or actors) when presenting an idea in
different mediums, including the representation/s or various perspectives of a subject or a key scene in
two different artistic mediums (e.g., a person’s life story in both print and multimedia), as well as what is
emphasized or absent in each work.

5365919E2D3B440DA1D4FD101F734F3B.description:
Analyze how an author conveys or develops their perspective or purpose in a text and by
acknowledging and responding to conflicting evidence or viewpoints.

729A8D87A7494306B7E794BD83C3E699.description:
Analyze how an author conveys or develops their perspective or purpose in a text through the
use of different perspectives of the characters and that of the audience or reader (e.g., created through
the use of dramatic irony).

401993AA609E473B84B49D2C762BBA05.description:
Analyze and explain how an author organizes, develops and presents ideas, establishes a point
of view or builds supporting arguments through text structure.

97701053A69246C7A1A4D8ED0BE3DCEC.description:
Compare and contrast the structure of texts, analyzing how the differing structure of each text
contributes to its meaning, tone and style.

D38C67B83A9C4008BA58F0DFA3A21189.description:
Analyze how particular elements of a text interact (e.g., how contexts influence individuals or
events, or how individuals influence ideas or events) across multiple text types, including across literary
and informational texts.

AB6E80DF4301469DBAB9404F1C64AE07.description:
Analyze how particular elements of a text interact (e.g., how setting shapes the characters or
plot, how ideas influence individuals or events, or how characters influence ideas or events) across
multiple text types, including across literary and informational texts.

DC7352FA3A264CA68E3B9D9E6CB286E2.description:
Determine a central idea of an informational text and how it is conveyed through particular
details; provide a summary of the text distinct from personal opinions or judgments.

357F42E05CE7473DA53FCEF3B81F9E28.description:
Determine a theme of a literary text and how it is conveyed through particular details; provide
a summary of the text distinct from personal opinions or judgments.

189837FDAC8B4E48BDC9C8D1532E4235.description:
Cite a range of textual evidence and make clear and relevant connections (including
informational text features such as charts, graphs, and diagrams) that strongly support an analysis of
multiple aspects of what an informational text says explicitly, as well as inferences drawn from the text.

2AF6DF845CD14C699FE0E08E098CB259.description:
Cite a range of textual evidence and make clear and relevant connections to strongly support
an analysis of multiple aspects of what a literary text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the
text.

88FCD638B1D64EFE9F981ABDA2CB098D.description:
Distinguish among the connotations (associations) of words with similar denotations
(definitions) (e.g., bullheaded, willful, firm, persistent, resolute).

99C6900D0B664BC9B126BCE81A8A9C74.description:
Analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or
allusions to other texts.

5B9D524CC9384852B74838856AF28032.description: Use the relationship between particular words to better understand each of the words.

768B0C16E8884DAF8D48B082A55CB1FA.description: Interpret figures of speech (e.g., verbal irony, puns) in context.

2E4115C413A94810A28F0F097EF7B25F.description:
Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word
meanings.

666FFF3C83C34FDEA1BE5D7D92D5471C.description:
Verify the preliminary determination of the meaning of a word or phrase (e.g., by checking
the inferred meaning in context or in a dictionary).

6102097C35FC4D1698A067867A532DCB.description:
Consult reference materials (e.g., dictionaries, glossaries, thesauruses), both print and
digital, to find the pronunciation of a word or determine or clarify its precise meaning or its
part of speech.

E04768B776F84C3EA9AE99D9A0366BA6.description:
Use common, grade-appropriate Greek or Latin affixes and roots as clues to the meaning of a
word (e.g., precede, recede, secede).

81C851F79DAC46F8B3509368143A6785.description: Analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone.

CE32490895814162B5435280EBD99787.description:
Use context (e.g., the overall meaning of a sentence or paragraph; a word’s position or
function in a sentence) as a clue to the meaning of a word or phrase.

6D230E08BD6C4631B79A25613A993980.description:
Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words or phrases based on
grade 8 reading and content, including technical meanings, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.

D62CCFBAD60D4E2C9E7F5B5B08C3A65F.description:
Use verbs in the active and passive voice and in the conditional and subjunctive mood to
achieve particular effects (e.g., emphasizing the actor or the action; expressing uncertainty
or describing a state contrary to fact).

14EF754E0D0545969E4A7B2A128F989E.description:
Gather vocabulary knowledge when selecting a word or phrase important to comprehension
or expression.

B9DE98537E04486A81CF41077572FA04.description:
Acquire and use accurately grade-appropriate general academic and domain-specific words
and phrases.

62C4D687B5B54FA9A29AC9D5EEA7F4C2.description: Use knowledge of language and its conventions when writing, speaking, reading, or listening.

7411951F987C4F5DBEEAA25CCDEC4088.description: Use an ellipsis to indicate an omission.

1774204C80F04233BBED5307088F82A8.description: Use punctuation (comma, ellipsis, dash) to indicate a pause or break.

FF555B93ECEA4A4D8F7C11C3AB020FDC.description: Recognize and correct inappropriate shifts in verb voice and mood.

58BC2A9239B549CE8CE45E52237870F1.description:
Form and use verbs in the indicative, imperative, interrogative, conditional, and subjunctive
mood.

82A2A787358A4427AEC2B26FDC5CF6C2.description: Form and use verbs in the active and passive voice.

047DE642270B449393050D271F966BA7.description:
Explain the function of verbals (gerunds, participles, infinitives) in general and their function
in particular sentences.

CA8EF0555C9E48378D363A9D4E485E1D.description:
Demonstrate command of the system and structure of the English language when writing or
speaking.
